title: For those interested in gpgcli
comment: I looked through a myriad directories for gpgcli.  It turns out it's not gpgcli, but gpg.  Back to review: this is a great beta of an app that has the potential to alter the landscape of Android security.  This is the only app I can think of right now that has a useful command line interface.

title: Richard Seepaul
comment: Does not work on Nexus 9 with Android 5.0.1 Suspect this is likely a PIE related Problem. (Position Independent Executable) Not looking for a "disable PIE" workaround; I prefer to wait for a compiled version of the App that is PIE functional with PIE or detects the Android version "automagically" and takes appropriate action to ensure functionality. There are likely a number of apps out there that do not work with Android L because of PIE.

title: Pretty good privacy if you don't care for privacy
comment: Anti-privacy app... crached when refusing access to contact list. Somewhat ironic..? App deleted.

If you are using an app to encrypt your secrets, then you should trust it enough to access your contacts, which are far from secret.  GPG uses the contacts permissions to sync the GPG keys to your People app, so you can easily view them.

title: Useless
comment: Have tried on two different tablets, has not worked properly on either.  First had remarkable crashes until program was uninstalled, second would not generate keys.  I have 20+ years experience with PGP.

title: Public keys disappear
comment: Imported public keys may vanish for no reason (and sometimes reapear later).  Far from usable right now.

title: Couldn't import private keys
comment: Several times I tried importing my secring.gpg file to import two or three of my existing private keys and it wouldn't show them in the private keys tab, though it would show up in the public key tabs. Without being able to import private keys, this application serves no purpose for me.
Doesn't. Work
The app is great and works well, but I'd love to see symmetric encryption/decryption as an option.
Symmetric encryption is available from the command line only, right now.

title: Pretty sneaky for a "We ant security for the world app".
comment: A security app should never do anything with out you knowing exactly what it is doing.  Went to look  up a phone number and I noticed a bunch of contacts that I did not create.  looking further I then noticed that it create an account on my device. I can not trust an app when it does things behind my back.

GPG uses the contacts permissions to sync the GPG keys to your People app, so you can easily view and use them.  One the setup screen, it tells you that "contacts integration" is enabled. If you are using an app to encrypt your secrets, then you should trust it enough to access your contacts, which are far from secret.

title: Can't import keys.
comment: The first key file fails to import (no error message) and I can't find a way to import subsequent keys.

title: Excellent
comment: Great implementation of gnupg for android. Just one thing... NEVER GENERATE ENCRYPTION KEYS ON SMARTPHONES. Most of these devices can't generate encryption keys with a good entropy, even with urandom Dev from Linux kernel, different from computers that have more physical devices with input data like mouse and keyboard. Generate your keys on PC and import them to your smartphone if you really care about security and anonymity.

title: Got a problem
comment: When I import my private key, it asks for a password, I never set up the key for a password based lock on the key, how do I import it?
waiting for integration with the native mail app. Please don't use K-9, the majority is moving away from Exchange 2003/2007.  Changing the review of course once this happens! :)

Unfortunately, I don't think it is possible to integrate with the native email app because we can't change it.  Any integration we could do with the native email app would be very limited and behave strangely.  We are now working on a common API so many apps can use GPG, so hopefully we'll get a better email client with PGP support.

title: Great
comment: It is a great app but every time I put in a acceptable passphrase it says failed to generate key any advice on what may help

title: Great work
comment: Thank you
I could not create a public/private key pair.

Yeah, the key creation process is a bit rough current.  Also, it can take a long time because Android does not seem to provide very much randomness/entropy to GnuPG.  It is probably easier to generate a key on a desktop, then export it and import it on Android.
Works fine.
Good start but needs more features

title: This is not even beta
comment: Android 4.2.2 -  Will not generate keys  Imports private key as public  Can't delete imported keys

I regularly import private keys with it, so it works sometimes. Can you file a bug report so I can fix the problem that you are having?
https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues/new

title: No encryption occurs
comment: Using the -c flag from the command line creates a .gpg file, however if you try to decrypt it, you will notice that it has only been changed to a PGP format, and no password is required to decrypt the produced file. That is, NO ENCRYPTION OCCURS despite a file being succesfully produced.

This is a bad situation, could you file a bug report so we can figure this out?
https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues/new

title: Batch generation
comment: When generating a key from the terminal or command line I have been using the --batch but it asks for a passphrase and that is kind of a pain for what I am doing is there some way to get rid of this?
This is a change in GnuPG itself in 2.x.  GPG for Android is based on GnuPG 2.1, so you have to find the new batch procedure for 2.1 to make it work.  I have not been able to get it working myself.

title: Not there yet. Keeping it anyway.
comment: Do hope folks will be able to get it working, friendly and integrated somehow. This is something that Android needs.

title: Excellent
comment: Needs more UI work. Please please please add clipboard encrypt/decrypt!

title: What's the point?
comment: Very buggy. Crashes all the time, even when not running. Does not integrate with gmail. Can't see any point to it.
We're working on adding K-9 integration to support PGP email, and of course fixing bugs as well. It is currently most useful for encrypting and signing sensitive files.

title: Latest update crashed until I ran the manual installer
comment: Updated review.  After the latest update, GPG kept crashing every few minutes.  I opened the application and it started an install script, copying files to /bin, /lib and so on.  GPG crashed in the middle of this process the first time, but I tried again and it successfully completed.  The repeated crashes have now stopped occurring.

title: Buggy
comment: Buggy, crash-prone, and no UI to add or generate keys.

title: Continually freezes
comment: Reports not working continuously even when doing unrelated things immediately uninstalled.

title: It works but it needs root.
comment: I am using Android 4.3. With Android Terminal Emulator, I can use this software only when I am root. Without root access it complains about permission denied and failure to load "libgcrypt.so.20". Hope to see this get fixed as most users won't bother to root their phones.   Anyway, thanks for the work. Keep it up.

It definitely should not need root at all.  To use it on the command line you need to add the aliases to the path, i.e.:
export PATH=/data/data/info.guardianproject.gpg/app_opt/aliases:$PATH

title: Can't seem to get it to encrypt
comment: Every time I try to share a file with Privacy Guard, I get a message saying that it can't detect what kind of file I'm sharing. These aren't anything special, either, just .docs and images.  Not sure if I didn't follow a step or something, and the problem's my fault, or if it's a bug.
Try the 0.3 release, encryption is working now.  If not, its a bug, please email support@guardianproject.info or file a bug report: https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues/new

title: Bummer..
comment: App worked for few mins before crash. Reported the crash, hope it gets fixed. Great concept, look forward to using app.  HTC DNA

There have been major improvements in the 0.3 release, please try it again.  If you have any problems, please email support@guardianproject.info or file a bug report: https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues/new

title: Crashing
comment: On the htc one the app is crashing on me, while using Android 4.1.1 HTC Sense 4+ without root. I tried it once with an import of my existing secret keyring which crashed, after that i tried without a key at all.  At last I tried using the standard install of Version 0.2 with key generation without any extra stuff (2048 Bit key RSA signing and encryption) and uploading to keyservers, now it worked okay to generate a key without crash but after that the app immediately crashed and could not be opened again as in the other two previous installs, I had to uninstall again. - waiting for the next release.

There have been major improvements in the 0.3 release, please try it again.  If you have any problems, please email support@guardianproject.info or file a bug report: https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues/new

title: Applaud the intention.
comment: But released before being even half finished. Constant crashes during and after setup on both Nexus 7 and Play Edition S4 running 4.3. When it works to the point of importing a key, the key disappears after an app restart. Frequent "library not found" messages. Etc. And a CLI-based UI is just a fundamentally wrong approach to a mobile app even if everything worked as intended. This project is worth keeping an eye on to see if it goes anywhere, but for now this isn't close to being ready for prime time.

The CLI was just to get things started, now we are working on a complete GUI. The 0.3 release includes a usable GUI.  If you have any problems, please email support@guardianproject.info or file a bug report: https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues/new

title: Force close
comment: Can't do any thing. Menu is not functioning. Can't decrypt. Force closes. need fix plz

There have been major improvements in the 0.3 release, please try it again. If you have any problems, please email support@guardianproject.info or file a bug report: https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues/new

title: Crashes
comment: Nothing but crashes on my HTC One.

title: Awesome
comment: Definitely a work in progress... The app always crashes on my phone, CLI works if I run gpg commands as su (by first typing "su" in terminal)... I assume the app would work great if it asked for root privileges... I wish I was capable of helping this project along, I think everybody should familiarize themselves with encryption technology... Privacy is a choice not a privilege...

Thanks! :-) It shouldn't need root at all.  You can definitely help move the project along by submitting bug reports.  A good bug report is often 90% of the work needed to fix the bug.  Please submit a bug report on this issue here:
https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues

title: Library problem on Android 4.3 (nexus 7)
comment: After upgrade to Android 4.3 launching gpg command from terminal emulator cause library not found problem. The complete error is:  /data/data/info.guardianproject.gpg/app_opt/etc/environment.conf: Permission denied CANNOT LINK EXECUTABLE: could not load library "libgcrypt.so.20" needed by "/data/data/info.guardianproject.gpg/app_opt/bin/gpg2"; caused by library "libgcrypt.so.20" not found
This sounds like the installation got corrupted.  Can you try uninstalling it and installing again?

title: Not work on Samsung Galaxy Pocket
comment: I use galaxy pocket and always get force closed when unpack install :(

Any information you can give us will help us fix this issue on your phone. For example, what are the messages that you see when it crashes?  Please submit the crash too.  Please submit a bug report here:
https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues

title: too many bugs
comment: 1. the app declines key deletion 2. pinentry errors  3. sometimes it can't decrypt and encrypt files. 4. impossible to import & export keys from files...

Please file bug reports!  We do know about some pinentry errors and have fixed a bunch recently, but encrypt/decrypt/import has been working for us, so it sounds like you are having issues that we haven't seen yet.

https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues
Atlast, gpg on android

title: Good
comment: Excellent tool! I absolutely love it :) it frequently needs restarting the service though.. a phone restart makes stuff which wasn't previously working to start working). Among things which don't work even after a phone restart is key signing. It keeps throwing me the syntax format despite the correct syntax - gpg --sign-key "Foo Bar"
we're working on fixing on the bugs.  Any feedback you can provide will help us improve the app.  Here's the bug tracker: https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/gpgandroid/issues

title: Pinentry problems
comment: I keep getting no pinentry error when I try to export private key.
We've fixed a bunch of pinentry problems, please try again and let us know if it is still not working for you!

title: Its Alright
comment: Ugh I hate resorting to terminal :p   its a pretty good app, finally a decent one for PGP type encryption.
We've just introduced a bunch of proper Android integration, with more work to come.  Try it out and let us know what you think about the direction we are taking.

title: Galaxy S4
comment: Occasionally I'll get a "no pinentry" error and have to restart the program. when the app loses focus it says "daemon stopped" not sure if that is intentional, or has anything to do with the "no pinentry" error.  Still pretty slick, and doesn't stop me from doing what I need to do and it'll get better with time. 5 stars.
Thanks! Stay tuned! we are about to release a big update that should include this fix!

title: I am almost in tears, I'm so happy
comment: I can't wait to wrap it up into other apps I build, too!

title: One of a kind!
comment: Finally, there's a full version of GnuPG on Android! This is the only version of PGP that is fully supported on Android right now. Great work!

title: Excellent
comment: OMG!! At last REAL GnuPG! On Android!! Outstanding!
